items.title: DAY 9 - LYNGEN ALPS
items.summary: Arctic Fjord Camp – Svensby (148 km) It’s up at…
items.content_html:
Arctic Fjord Camp – Svensby (148 km)

It’s up at 06.00 am and out of the door at 07.00 am. The drive to the ferry at Olderdalen takes about 2 hours under normal circumstances. We do take longer, though, because the views to the Lyngen Alps across the fjord are so spectacular that we have to stop ever so often for photographs.

We take the ferry at 10.05 am and arrive on the other side about 45 minutes later. Our little apartment in Svensby is ready for check-in when we get there at 11.40 am, and after dumping some stuff off we go on a first little walk to the tip of Lenangsøyra.

On the way back we buy some traditional cinnamon buns to last us for the next activities: Julie is riding little brommy back to the ranch while I go on the 3 hour hike to lake Blåisvatnet. And after that it's winding down back at our place for the night after another great day.

items.title: DAY 8 - ARCTIC FJORD CAMP
items.summary: Around the Arctic Fjord Camp (76 km) The day starts…
items.content_html:
Around the Arctic Fjord Camp (76 km)

The day starts early at 04.00 am after a really good night. The sunrise over the fjord and mountains in the background is magical. We are out of the house before 07.00 am to have a little exploratory drive to Jøkelfjord, some 20 km into the next bay.

An hour later we are back for breakfast, then head off along the shoreline to Storengneset, a little viewpoint not too far from our Camp. After that little wander, we go separate ways; Julie to do a bit more twitching and take baby Brommy out for a little ride; and I go for a hike to a nice viewpoint of Jøkelfjord glacier. The weather couldn’t be better and I almost wished I had put some shorts on instead of long trousers.

In the afternoon we hang around the cottage and take a quick dip in the fjord. A real quick one, in fact. It’s bloody freezing.

items.title: DAY 7 - ARCTIC FJORD CAMP
items.summary: Gjisvær – Arctic Fjord Camp (323 km) We both wake…
items.content_html:
Gjisvær – Arctic Fjord Camp (323 km)

We both wake up more or less at the same time at around 06.30 am. It’s still blowing a hooley outside and it’s raining almost horizontally. We are glad to have had the luck to experience this incredible place in the sunshine yesterday and are, therefore, not that sad to be leaving at around 09.30 am.

Despite the weather, the drive is very interesting and varied, as the atmosphere changes quickly with clouds moving fast and the occasional ray of sunshine peaking through.

Just before our next destination, the Arctic Fjord Camp, we branch off the main road to do a hikelet to some springs in the woods, the Bubbelen. After that, it’s straight to our cabin right by the shore of some fjord. What can I say? Every time I think it can’t get any better, it does!

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 6 PM - BIRD SAFARI
items.summary: The all-you-can-eat-buffet tourists from the Hurtigruten cruise arrive almost half…
items.content_html:
The all-you-can-eat-buffet tourists from the Hurtigruten cruise arrive almost half an hour late. Having finally graced us with their presence, it’s off to an almost 2 hour boat trip during which we see a lot of flying objects of all sorts. Some of them also do some diving into the water. And some are already in the water. But they aren’t of the flying sort. They are seals.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 6 AM - NORTHCAPE
items.summary: Gjisvær – Northcape – Skarsvåg – Gjisvær (84 km) We…
items.content_html:
Gjisvær – Northcape – Skarsvåg – Gjisvær (84 km)

We head off from Gisvær to the Northcape at 06.40 am. It’s exactly at 07.25 am that we arrive at Europe’s most northerly point. The masses have not yet invaded the place for today, so we are lucky enough to not have the views blocked by the human herds.

The rain from last night has stopped and the last remaining clouds move off to the East, too. This is the coldest I have been yet on the trip, even though the temperature is 10 degrees and the wind not too strong. I don’t want to know how that must be with gale force gusts and close to the freezing point.

After about half an hour we move on to Skarsvåg for a little hike up to a viewpoint, the Kirkeporten. It reminds us of Durdle Door in Dorset. Back home at 10.15 am, it’s coffee and breakfast time before getting the tickets for our 11.45 boat safari out to the offshore islands for some bird watching.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 5 - NORTHCAPE
items.summary: Alta – Gjisvær (241 km) After a little bit of…
items.content_html:
Alta – Gjisvær (241 km)

After a little bit of a longer lie-in until about 6.30 am, it’s first a trip to the supermarket to get some provisions for our little house up on the Northcape before enjoying a superb breakfast in our guesthouse. After packing up, we are off to the Alta Museum, a World Heritage Rock Art Centre. As we come to learn, Alta has more rock art made by hunter-gatherers than any other place in northern Europe.

At 11 am we are on our way to the most northern part of this trip. It’s meant to be a 3,5 hour drive up to Gjisvær on the Northcape peninsula where we are renting a little Fisherman’s cottage right by the sea. However, we take much longer than that, as there is a fabulous photo stop basically around every corner.

The reindeer begin to get a bit boring as they are now appearing in the hundreds. It has to be said, though, that they are a bit better behaved than in Sweden and mostly stay out of harm’s way off the main road.

At 4 pm we finally arrive at our accomodation. It has started to rain, but we don’t care. This place is amazing in any kind of weather. And we might be lucky tomorrow morning when we will make the final push towards Europe’s most northerly point.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 4 - THREE COUNTRIES
items.summary: Arvidsjaur – Alta (723 km) As it has been a…
items.content_html:
Arvidsjaur – Alta (723 km)

As it has been a while since I last changed plans, it’s a change of plans today. Initially, I had wanted to drive the stretch up to Alta in the North of Norway in two days. But why do in two what you could do in one (very long one)? And it’ll make the last push for the Northcape on Friday a little less tiresome. The drive is going to take me from Sweden, through a short stretch of Finland, into Norway.

Due to another short night, it’s a very early start. Exactly at 4.30 am I am on the road. The morning light couldn’t be more beautiful, and as the sun rises into misty skies, the colours appear almost surreal. Santa’s gang is out and about again as well, but – contrary to the ones I come across in Norway later into my drive - on the Swedish side they at least have the decency to stand in the middle of the road so that you can see them. Strangely, the only country where you can’t see any of these buggers is Finland. Or perhaps not that strange, as this is the REAL Santa country. Perhaps there they DO take their job seriously and have started the Christmas preparations instead of wandering about on country roads hindering the tourists.

I reach Alta around 3 pm, more or less at the same time Julie arrives by plane via Oslo from Heathrow. Good bye to lonely days!

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 3 - SWEDEN
items.summary: Östersund – Arvidsjaur (468 km) The plan to sleep in…
items.content_html:
Östersund – Arvidsjaur (468 km)

The plan to sleep in late before starting on the fifth leg is out of the window at 5.30 am. So it’s up at 6 am instead of the intended 9 am. And I am on the road by 7.45 am.

The day begins with a slight drizzle on my windscreen and only starts brightening up 2 hours into my 6-hour drive. As yesterday, the sun slowly emerges from the clouds the further up North I get. Once into Lapland, I realize that I need to be careful with road traffic. Not the motorized one, though. Santa’s little helpers are all over the place and seem to have a death wish. Perhaps they are dreading the approaching Christmas period…

I reach my overnight place, the Lapland Lodge in Arvidsjaur, at 2 pm. As it is bright and sunny, off I go on my two-wheeler for a little exploratory of the surroundings.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 2 - SWEDEN
items.summary: Kristinehamn – Östersund (524 km) Fourth leg – all according…
items.content_html:
Kristinehamn – Östersund (524 km)

Fourth leg – all according to plan. The longest driving day so far starts with an overcast sky and some drops of rain but gets brighter and sunnier the further up North I get. The landscape is mostly foresty, and the lakes are getting bigger. I stop for a quick picnic at a nice spot overlooking one of the many lakes en route and arrive at my destination near Öresund shortly after 4 pm. The place I’ve booked couldn’t be more scenic, it’s a house right by the water. It even comes with a pier and some jet skies. However, I manage to not give in to the temptation to take one of them to go into town and unfold my two-wheeled little red friend instead for a late afternoon ride.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 1 - SWEDEN
items.summary: Klagsham – Kristinehamn (498 km) Third leg - no change…
items.content_html:
Klagsham – Kristinehamn (498 km)

Third leg - no change of plans for a change. It’s the first whole driving day in Sweden, and it’s a very smooth run to my next accomodation near Kristinehamn. The countryside is what I would describe as typical Swedish with loads of trees and the odd lake thrown in for good measure.

My place for the night is a small cottage in the middle of nowhere. The hosts are very host-like, indeed, and - upon arrival - I am being served coffee, a sandwich and a muffin on the deck overlooking a little pond.

After having been culinarily satisfied, it’s time to get equally satisfied from the EXERCISE point of view; so I jump on my bike to explore the area around Kristinehamn. It is blowing a hooley making the going quite tough at times, particularly when the gusts come directly from the front.
